questions.q: In horticultural labels, “full sun” typically means:
questions.explain: Most plant labels and extension references use full sun as at least about 6 hours of direct sunlight.

questions.q: “Part shade” most often describes a site with:
questions.explain: Part shade commonly means some direct sun (often morning) but protection from intense afternoon sun.

questions.q: What does “well-drained soil” mean in practice?
choices: Excess water drains while soil stays evenly moist
questions.explain: Well-drained soils allow excess water to move through while still holding moisture for roots.

questions.q: Which soil texture generally holds the most water?
questions.explain: Clay’s very small particles and high surface area allow it to retain more water.

questions.q: Soil compaction most directly harms plants by reducing:
questions.explain: Compaction reduces pore space, limiting oxygen diffusion to roots and water infiltration.

questions.q: A reliable way to understand soil pH is that it affects:
choices: How available nutrients are to plants
questions.explain: Soil pH strongly influences nutrient availability and uptake, even if nutrients are present.

questions.q: Overwatering most commonly damages plants because it:
questions.explain: Saturated soils displace oxygen; roots can suffocate and become susceptible to rot.

questions.q: Which is the most reliable indicator that a plant needs watering?
questions.explain: Check soil moisture below the surface; wilting can occur from heat stress even when soil is moist.

questions.q: For many landscapes, the most efficient irrigation timing is:
questions.explain: Early morning reduces evaporation and leaf wetness duration compared to night watering.

questions.q: When planting a tree, the root flare should be:
choices: At or slightly above finished grade
questions.explain: Planting too deep is a leading failure cause; the root flare should be visible at/above grade.

questions.q: A good planting hole for a tree is generally:
choices: As deep as the root ball and 2–3× as wide
Same width as the root ball
questions.explain: Depth should match the root ball; a wide hole encourages lateral root expansion.

questions.q: After planting, the most important immediate care is usually:
questions.explain: Establishment success depends heavily on consistent, deep watering (not fertilizer) early on.

questions.q: The main benefit of mulch around plants is to:
questions.explain: Mulch moderates temperature, reduces evaporation, and suppresses weeds.

questions.q: Mulch should be kept away from direct contact with tree trunks to prevent:
questions.explain: Mulch piled against trunks traps moisture and encourages decay and pests (“mulch volcano”).

questions.q: A typical recommended mulch depth for many landscapes is about:
questions.explain: Around 2–3 inches is commonly recommended; too deep can reduce oxygen and hold excess moisture.

questions.q: The safest general time to prune many deciduous trees is:
questions.explain: Dormant pruning reduces stress and is often less favorable for many pathogens and insects.

questions.q: Why should you avoid leaving a long stub when pruning a branch?
choices: It prevents callus formation and can decay
questions.explain: Stubs don’t seal properly and can die back and decay, creating entry points for pests and disease.

questions.q: If a shrub blooms on old wood (forms buds the previous season), a general pruning rule is to prune:
questions.explain: Pruning right after flowering avoids removing next season’s flower buds formed on old wood.

questions.q: Excessive fertilizer can harm plants primarily by:
choices: Root burn and disrupted water uptake
questions.explain: High salts from overfertilization can damage roots and interfere with water absorption.

questions.q: On a fertilizer label like 10-10-10, the numbers represent:
questions.explain: The numbers indicate the percent of nitrogen, phosphorus (as phosphate), and potassium (as potash).

questions.q: Which is the best first step before deciding to fertilize a landscape?
questions.explain: Soil tests guide whether nutrients are needed and help avoid over-application.

questions.q: Photosynthesis primarily uses sunlight to convert:
choices: Carbon dioxide and water into sugars
questions.explain: Photosynthesis uses CO₂ and water to produce sugars (chemical energy), releasing oxygen as a byproduct.

questions.q: Transpiration is best described as:
choices: Water loss from leaves that helps move water/nutrients
questions.explain: Transpiration is water vapor loss through stomata; it drives water movement through the plant.

questions.q: Stomata are primarily responsible for:
questions.explain: Stomata open/close to regulate CO₂ intake and water loss.

questions.q: Chlorosis is most often seen as:
questions.explain: Chlorosis is yellowing from reduced chlorophyll, often tied to nutrient issues or pH-related lockout.

questions.q: Leaf scorch usually refers to:
choices: Brown, dry leaf margins from stress
questions.explain: Scorch commonly appears as browning at edges/tips from water stress, heat, salt, or root damage.

questions.q: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) emphasizes:
choices: Monitoring and using least-disruptive controls first
questions.explain: IPM focuses on scouting, thresholds, and targeted controls to minimize impacts and resistance.

questions.q: Many foliar fungal diseases spread most easily when leaves are:
questions.explain: Leaf wetness duration is a key driver for many fungal and bacterial infections.

questions.q: Aphids often cause which symptom on new growth?
questions.explain: Aphids feed on sap, distorting tender growth and excreting honeydew that can lead to sooty mold.

questions.q: Powdery mildew is typically recognized by:
questions.explain: Powdery mildew looks like a white/gray coating and often occurs with humid air and moderate temps.

questions.q: Why is it generally better to water at the soil level rather than overhead for many plants?
choices: It reduces leaf wetness and disease risk
questions.explain: Overhead watering can keep foliage wet longer, promoting foliar diseases.

questions.q: A key reason weeds thrive in thin turf is:
choices: Bare soil and low competition from grass
questions.explain: Weeds exploit open space; dense turf shades soil and competes effectively for resources.

questions.q: Preemergent herbicides primarily target weeds by:
questions.explain: Preemergents act on germinating seeds/seedlings; timing before germination is essential.

questions.q: Asexual (vegetative) propagation produces plants that are:
questions.explain: Cuttings/division/layering typically produce clones with the same genetics as the parent plant.

questions.q: Which method is commonly used to propagate many houseplants quickly?
questions.explain: Stem cuttings are a common, efficient method for many houseplants.

questions.q: Cold stratification is used to:
choices: Break seed dormancy in some species
questions.explain: Some seeds require a moist chilling period to break dormancy and germinate reliably.

questions.q: “Hardening off” seedlings means:
choices: Gradually acclimating plants to outdoor conditions
questions.explain: Hardening off reduces transplant shock by slowly increasing sun, wind, and temperature exposure.

questions.q: A common reason container plants fail is:
questions.explain: Containers must drain well; waterlogged media quickly leads to root stress and rot.

questions.q: Why do container plants typically need more frequent watering than in-ground plants?
choices: Potting mixes drain faster and have less total soil volume
Roots don’t absorb water in pots
Mulch can’t be used in pots
questions.explain: Less volume and faster drainage mean containers dry out more quickly than ground soil.

questions.q: Finished compost is best described as:
choices: Stable, dark organic matter with earthy smell
questions.explain: Finished compost is decomposed, stable organic material that improves soil structure and biology.

questions.q: A good compost pile generally needs:
choices: A mix of greens and browns plus moisture and oxygen
questions.explain: Composting works best with balanced carbon/nitrogen inputs, adequate moisture, and oxygen.

questions.q: The single best cultural practice to reduce many turf problems is:
choices: Mowing at the correct height for the species
questions.explain: Proper mowing height supports deeper roots and denser turf, suppressing weeds and stress.

questions.q: Why is frequent shallow watering discouraged for lawns?
choices: It encourages shallow roots and increases stress susceptibility
questions.explain: Shallow watering promotes shallow roots; deeper, less frequent watering generally builds resilience.

questions.q: Why is staking a newly planted tree often unnecessary or limited in duration?
choices: It makes the trunk too flexible
It can reduce trunk strength development if left too long
questions.explain: Some movement helps trunks strengthen; prolonged staking can lead to weak trunks and girdling ties.

questions.q: Girdling roots are problematic because they can:
choices: Constrict water/nutrient flow and destabilize the tree
questions.explain: Roots circling and tightening around the trunk can restrict vascular flow and weaken stability over time.

questions.q: “Rejuvenation pruning” on some shrubs generally involves:
choices: Cutting many stems down near the base to renew growth
questions.explain: Many multi-stem shrubs can be renewed by removing older stems near the base to stimulate new shoots.

questions.q: Nitrogen deficiency most commonly shows as:
questions.explain: Nitrogen is mobile in plants, so deficiency symptoms often appear first on older leaves.

questions.q: Iron deficiency commonly appears as:
choices: Yellowing between veins on newest leaves
questions.explain: Iron is relatively immobile; deficiency often shows as interveinal chlorosis on young leaves.

questions.q: Why do plants often wilt in hot afternoon sun even when soil is moist?
questions.explain: High heat and sun increase transpiration; plants may wilt temporarily even with adequate soil moisture.

questions.q: What is the primary reason frost can injure tender plants?
choices: Ice formation damages plant cells and tissues
questions.explain: Freezing can rupture cells and disrupt tissues; tender plants lack cold hardiness.

questions.q: A key first step in diagnosing a plant problem is to:
choices: Correctly identify the plant and observe symptoms/patterns
questions.explain: Accurate identification and pattern observation are foundational; treatment depends on correct diagnosis.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of adding organic matter (like compost) to mineral soil?
choices: To permanently raise soil pH by 2 points
To improve soil structure, moisture behavior, and microbial activity
To replace the need for irrigation
questions.explain: Organic matter improves aggregation/tilth, moderates moisture, and supports soil biology; it doesn't sterilize soil or eliminate irrigation.

questions.q: In Zone 5–6, which timing is generally best for transplanting most hardy perennials to reduce stress?
choices: Early spring or early fall when temperatures are moderate
Only when the plant is in full bloom
questions.explain: Cooler temps and steadier moisture in spring/fall usually improve establishment.

questions.q: Which practice most reduces the risk of spreading soil-borne disease between beds?
choices: Sanitizing tools and avoiding moving contaminated soil
questions.explain: Sanitation and limiting soil movement reduce disease spread; deep planting and excess nitrogen can worsen problems.

questions.q: On many herbaceous perennials, what does “crown” refer to?
choices: The junction of stems and roots near soil level
The top of a tree canopy
A ring of bark around a limb
questions.explain: The crown is the transition between stems and roots; burying it often promotes rot.

questions.q: In pruning, what does a “thinning cut” do?
choices: Removes an entire branch back to its origin
questions.explain: Thinning removes whole branches to open the canopy and improve light/air movement.

questions.q: A common sign of waterlogged roots (vs drought) is:
choices: Soil is dry several inches down
Yellowing leaves while soil stays wet and growth stalls
Crispy margins after hot wind only
Plant perks up quickly after watering
questions.explain: Saturated roots lose oxygen and function, causing yellowing and stalling even with wet soil.

questions.q: Why can thick mulch over newly seeded areas be a problem?
choices: Mulch lowers oxygen in the air
Mulch can block emergence and keep the surface too wet/cool
questions.explain: Many seedlings need easy emergence and appropriate moisture; thick mulch can hinder both.

questions.q: Which statement about drainage in containers is most accurate?
choices: A gravel layer at the bottom improves drainage in most pots
Drainage depends on holes and a suitable potting mix
Drainage holes are optional if you water carefully
questions.explain: Holes + proper media matter most; gravel layers often worsen perched water in containers.

questions.q: Why remove fallen, diseased leaves under susceptible plants?
choices: Many pathogens overwinter on debris and re-infect next season
questions.explain: Sanitation reduces overwintering inoculum and cuts down next-season reinfection.

questions.q: Which is a “cultural control” in IPM?
choices: Only releasing predators in every case
questions.explain: Cultural controls change conditions to reduce pressure (spacing, sanitation, irrigation, pruning).

questions.q: In Zones 5–6, which hydrangea type is most reliable for blooming because it flowers on new wood?
questions.explain: Panicle hydrangeas bloom on new wood, so winter damage is less likely to eliminate flowering.

questions.q: A key landscape advantage of serviceberry (Amelanchier) in Zones 5–6 is:
choices: It offers spring flowers, edible berries, and fall color
questions.explain: Serviceberries provide multi-season interest and are commonly hardy in Zones 5–6.

questions.q: Emerald ash borer primarily attacks which genus?
questions.explain: EAB targets ash (Fraxinus).

questions.q: Japanese beetle feeding often results in:
questions.explain: Adults commonly skeletonize foliage by eating tissue between veins.

questions.q: Fire blight is most associated with:
choices: Apple/pear relatives and blackened shoot tips
questions.explain: Fire blight commonly affects Rosaceae (e.g., apple, pear, crabapple) and scorches shoots.

questions.q: Why do some birches decline when planted in hot, dry, reflective sites?
choices: Stress can predispose them to borers and dieback
They only grow in pure sand
questions.explain: Heat/drought stress can weaken birch and increase susceptibility to decline and borers.

questions.q: Which is a common Zone 5–6 native ornamental grass with upright clumps?
questions.explain: Switchgrass is a common native ornamental for Zones 5–6; the others are warm-region turf grasses.

questions.q: A common reason peonies fail to bloom is:
questions.explain: Peony buds planted too deep often reduce flowering; they prefer shallow planting.

questions.q: Black walnut produces juglone, which can:
choices: Inhibit growth of some sensitive plants nearby
Eliminate all insects in the area
questions.explain: Juglone can be allelopathic to certain plants; sensitivity varies by species.

questions.q: What is a key reason to rotate vegetable crops by family each year?
choices: It reduces buildup of family-specific pests and diseases
questions.explain: Rotation helps break pest/disease cycles tied to crop families.

questions.q: Blossom end rot in tomatoes is most often triggered by:
questions.explain: Moisture swings limit calcium movement to developing fruit, causing the disorder.

questions.q: A “cover crop” is primarily grown to:
choices: Protect soil, suppress weeds, and add organic matter (sometimes nitrogen)
questions.explain: Cover crops protect and build soil; legumes can contribute nitrogen.

questions.q: Which cover crop type is best known for nitrogen fixation?
questions.explain: Legumes host nitrogen-fixing bacteria in root nodules.

questions.q: What is a “perched water table” in a container context?
choices: Water floating above gravel improves drainage
Water held above a textural boundary within the pot
questions.explain: Media physics can hold water above a boundary; gravel layers often increase water retention above them.

questions.q: What is “thatch” in turf?
choices: A layer of dead/decaying stems and roots between soil and green blades
questions.explain: Thatch is an organic layer that can impede infiltration if excessive.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of core aeration?
choices: Improve infiltration, oxygen exchange, and root growth
Remove all thatch in one pass
questions.explain: Aeration relieves compaction and improves soil-air-water relationships for roots.

questions.q: A systemic pesticide is best described as one that:
choices: Is taken up by the plant and affects pests feeding from within
questions.explain: Systemics are absorbed and translocated through plant tissues.

questions.q: In Zones 5–6, a common winter issue for broadleaf evergreens is:
questions.explain: Sun and wind can dry foliage when frozen roots can't replace water.

questions.q: Why avoid heavy late-season nitrogen on woody plants in Zones 5–6?
choices: It can push tender growth that won’t harden off before frost
questions.explain: Late tender growth is more vulnerable to winter injury.

questions.q: Which irrigation method is typically most water-efficient for vegetables?
questions.explain: Drip/soaker delivers water to root zones with minimal evaporation and reduced leaf wetness.

questions.q: Why can tilling a weed-free bed lead to a flush of weeds afterward?
choices: Tilling sterilizes soil and creates weeds
Tilling brings dormant seeds to light/air and favorable germination conditions
questions.explain: Disturbance exposes buried seeds and triggers germination.

questions.q: Which symptom commonly indicates de-icing salt injury near roads?
choices: Brown leaf/needle tips and margins, worse on road-facing side
questions.explain: Salt spray/uptake often causes tip/margin burn, especially on exposure sides.

questions.q: Why are spring bulbs typically planted in fall in Zones 5–6?
choices: They require hot soil to sprout
They need a cold period to root and satisfy dormancy requirements
They must be planted during bloom
questions.explain: Fall planting allows rooting and cold conditioning for strong spring growth.

questions.q: A classic sign of deer browsing on woody shrubs is:
questions.explain: Deer browsing often leaves ragged ends because of their dentition.

questions.q: Best protection against rabbit girdling on young trees is:
questions.explain: Physical barriers prevent bark chewing that can girdle stems.

questions.q: On a grafted fruit tree, a sucker is usually:
choices: A shoot arising from below the graft union (rootstock growth)
questions.explain: Below-graft shoots are typically rootstock and should be removed.

questions.q: Why keep the graft union above soil level?
choices: To prevent scion rooting and preserve rootstock traits
questions.explain: Burying graft unions can negate rootstock benefits and increase disease risk.

questions.q: Composting weeds with mature seeds is safest when:
choices: Hot composting reaches sustained high temperatures
questions.explain: Cool compost piles often fail to kill seeds; hot composting is more reliable.

questions.q: Why do conifers make good windbreaks in Zones 5–6?
choices: They provide year-round wind reduction due to evergreen foliage
questions.explain: Evergreen foliage reduces wind even in winter when deciduous trees are bare.

questions.q: Soil texture refers to:
choices: Proportions of sand, silt, and clay
questions.explain: Texture is particle size distribution, influencing drainage and water holding.

questions.q: Soil structure refers to:
choices: How particles form aggregates and pore spaces
questions.explain: Structure is aggregation and pore arrangement, affecting infiltration and root growth.

questions.q: Which action is most likely to improve a poorly structured clay soil over time?
choices: Adding organic matter and minimizing compaction
Adding a small amount of sand
questions.explain: Organic matter supports aggregation; minimizing compaction preserves pore spaces.

questions.q: Why can adding a little sand to clay soil make it worse?
choices: Certain ratios can create a dense, cement-like mix
questions.explain: Clay + insufficient sand + low organic matter can pack tightly like mortar.

questions.q: A taproot system is best described as:
choices: One dominant root with smaller laterals
Roots that grow only in water
questions.explain: Taprooted plants have a main central root; disturbance can be harder on established plants.

questions.q: Why can string trimmers be deadly to young trees?
choices: They can girdle bark/cambium at the base
questions.explain: Repeated bark injury at the base can girdle the tree and interrupt vascular flow.

questions.q: Black spot on roses is favored by:
choices: Prolonged leaf wetness and poor airflow
questions.explain: Wet foliage and low airflow favor infection; sanitation and resistant cultivars help.

questions.q: Fungicide resistance risk is highest when:
choices: Different modes of action are rotated
The same mode of action is used repeatedly
questions.explain: Repeated use of one mode of action selects for resistant pathogen populations.

questions.q: Large irregular holes in hosta leaves, often overnight, are commonly caused by:
questions.explain: Slugs/snails feed at night and leave irregular holes (often with slime trails).

questions.q: Scale insects on woody plants are typically:
choices: Sap-feeding insects that appear as bumps on stems/leaves
questions.explain: Scale feed on sap and can weaken plants; some produce honeydew leading to sooty mold.

questions.q: Preemergent herbicides should generally be avoided when you plan to seed soon because:
choices: They can inhibit desired seed germination/establishment too
questions.explain: Preemergents act on germinating seeds/seedlings, including turf seed.

questions.q: Damping-off is best described as:
choices: Seedlings collapsing at the soil line from disease
questions.explain: Damping-off pathogens can kill seedlings at the soil line, favored by wet, stagnant conditions.

questions.q: Which practice most reduces damping-off risk?
choices: Clean trays, well-drained media, and avoiding constant saturation
Warm stagnant air and deep shade
Using garden soil in seed trays
questions.explain: Sanitation + drainage + moisture control reduce risk; garden soil often carries pathogens and drains poorly.

questions.q: A typical benefit of planting native milkweed in Zones 5–6 is:
choices: It supports monarch butterflies as a larval host
questions.explain: Milkweeds are key host plants for monarch larvae and provide nectar resources.

questions.q: Why can repeated shallow cultivation around tree roots be harmful?
choices: It severs fine roots and reduces uptake capacity
questions.explain: Fine roots near the surface are important for uptake; repeated disturbance reduces vigor.

questions.q: Mycorrhizal fungi primarily:
choices: Enhance water/nutrient uptake via symbiosis with roots
questions.explain: They can increase effective root surface area and improve uptake, especially in nutrient-poor soils.

questions.q: Why are apples often planted with a second compatible variety nearby?
choices: To improve cross-pollination and fruit set
questions.explain: Many apple varieties benefit from cross-pollination with a compatible bloom-time partner.

questions.q: What is “biennial bearing” in fruit trees?
choices: Heavy crop one year followed by a light crop the next
questions.explain: Some trees alternate heavy/light years; thinning and good care can help moderate it.

questions.q: Why thin apples or peaches on the tree?
choices: To improve size/quality and reduce limb breakage
questions.explain: Thinning reduces competition, improves quality, and helps prevent limb damage and alternate bearing.

questions.q: Bolting in lettuce/spinach refers to:
choices: Premature flowering that often makes leaves bitter/tough
questions.explain: Heat/long days often trigger early flowering, reducing eating quality.

questions.q: A raised bed’s main advantage is typically:
choices: Improved drainage and faster warming in spring
questions.explain: Raised beds often drain better and warm earlier, improving growth and access.

questions.q: Which amendment is most likely to raise soil pH?
questions.explain: Lime raises pH; sulfur lowers pH.

questions.q: Which is a common reason arborvitae browns out on one side in winter?
choices: Winter wind/sun desiccation on exposure side
questions.explain: Evergreens can desiccate in winter, especially on the wind/sun-facing side.

questions.q: Photoperiod means:
questions.explain: Many plants respond to day length for flowering and developmental timing.

questions.q: A common reason houseplants decline in winter is:
choices: Reduced light and cold drafts/dry indoor air stress
questions.explain: Winter light drops; windows can be cold/drafty and indoor air often dries out.

questions.q: Pinching basil primarily:
questions.explain: Removing the tip promotes branching and maintains leafy growth longer.

questions.q: Why is edging around a bed helpful?
choices: It reduces turf creep and makes maintenance cleaner
questions.explain: Defined edges reduce encroachment and simplify mulching and trimming.

questions.q: Interior browning of older needles on many conifers is often:
choices: Normal seasonal shedding of older interior needles
questions.explain: Many conifers shed older interior needles periodically; pattern and timing matter.

questions.q: Why might newly installed sod fail to root into soil below?
choices: Poor sod-to-soil contact and insufficient establishment watering
questions.explain: Air gaps and poor moisture management prevent roots from knitting into the underlying soil.

questions.q: Native meadow seedings most often succeed when you prioritize:
choices: Thorough site prep and aggressive early weed control
questions.explain: Early weed pressure is the biggest failure point; prep and follow-up control are crucial.

questions.q: Soil temperature matters for germination because:
choices: All seeds germinate at the same temperature
Different species have different optimal temperature ranges
questions.explain: Germination is species-specific; temperature strongly influences speed and success.

questions.q: Forsythia is best known in Zones 5–6 for:
choices: Yellow flowers on bare stems in early spring
questions.explain: Forsythia is a classic early spring bloomer with yellow flowers before/with leaf emergence.

questions.q: A common reason bedding plants decline when planted repeatedly in the same spot is:
choices: Localized pests/diseases can build up over time
questions.explain: Repeated host planting can increase localized pest and disease pressure.

questions.q: What is a key reason to avoid working wet clay soil?
choices: It smears/compacts easily and destroys structure
questions.explain: Wet clay compacts and smears, reducing pore space and harming structure.

questions.q: In a compost pile, “greens” are primarily:
questions.explain: Greens supply nitrogen; browns supply carbon.

questions.q: A common sign of insufficient airflow in indoor seed starting is:
choices: Leggy seedlings and increased disease risk
questions.explain: Low airflow and low light contribute to leggy growth and disease pressure.

questions.q: What does CEC (cation exchange capacity) broadly relate to?
choices: How well soil can hold positively charged nutrients
questions.explain: CEC is linked to soil’s ability to retain nutrient cations (and buffer fertility).

questions.q: Why is chlorinated municipal water usually acceptable for general garden watering?
choices: Typical levels dissipate and generally do not harm landscape plants
questions.explain: At typical municipal levels it’s generally fine for landscape use; sensitive closed systems can differ.

questions.q: A rain garden is primarily designed to:
questions.explain: Rain gardens manage runoff by slowing, capturing, and infiltrating water using suitable plants.

questions.q: Verticillium wilt often shows as:
choices: Sudden wilting/dieback often on one side or one branch
questions.explain: It commonly causes uneven branch wilting/dieback because vascular tissues are affected.

questions.q: Boxwood winter bronzing is often worsened by:
questions.explain: Wind/sun can dry foliage in winter, leading to bronzing/burn.

questions.q: When overseeding a lawn, the most important factor for success is:
choices: Seed on top of thick thatch
Good seed-to-soil contact plus consistent moisture
questions.explain: Seed-to-soil contact and steady moisture are critical; preemergents can prevent establishment.

questions.q: Why do many fruit trees need “chill hours”?
choices: To satisfy dormancy requirements for normal bloom
questions.explain: Chilling helps break dormancy; insufficient chill can reduce flowering and fruit set.

questions.q: The three-cut method for large limb removal is mainly to:
choices: Prevent bark tearing and trunk damage
questions.explain: It prevents the limb’s weight from ripping bark down the trunk as it drops.

questions.q: Why is wound paint generally discouraged on most tree pruning cuts?
choices: It can trap moisture and does not improve natural compartmentalization
It prevents any pest from landing
questions.explain: Most trees seal wounds via compartmentalization; paints often don’t help and can worsen conditions.

questions.q: Norway maple (Acer platanoides) is often disliked in landscapes because it:
choices: Can form dense shallow roots and heavy shade that suppress understory plants
questions.explain: It can create difficult growing conditions beneath its canopy due to root competition and shade.

questions.q: In Zones 5–6, which is a common symptom of salt spray on evergreens?
choices: Tip browning on needles on the road-facing side
questions.explain: Salt spray injury often concentrates on exposed sides and shows as tip burn.

questions.q: Why do marginal buds become more vulnerable as they swell in spring?
choices: Hardiness decreases as dormancy breaks and tissues rehydrate
questions.explain: As buds swell, tissues are more active and less freeze-tolerant.

questions.q: A major benefit of planting oaks (Quercus spp.) is:
choices: Long lifespan and high wildlife/ecological value
questions.explain: Oaks are valued for longevity and ecosystem support; no tree is pest-immune.

questions.q: Why can container plants show drought stress sooner than in-ground plants?
choices: Less soil volume and faster drainage increase drying
Roots don’t absorb water in containers
Mulch cannot be used in pots
questions.explain: Containers have limited media volume and often drain/dry faster than garden soils.

questions.q: A good reason to mulch vegetable beds is:
choices: It moderates moisture and suppresses weeds
questions.explain: Mulch reduces evaporation and weed germination; it doesn’t replace rotation or IPM.

questions.q: Why is “planting on a mound” sometimes used for shrubs in heavy clay?
choices: To improve drainage around the root zone
questions.explain: Mounding lifts roots above saturated zones, improving oxygen and reducing rot risk.

questions.q: When a plant is 'rootbound,' the best planting correction is usually to:
choices: Plant it as-is to avoid disturbance
Loosen/slice outer circling roots to encourage outward growth
questions.explain: Correcting circling roots helps prevent future girdling and improves establishment.

questions.q: A classic vegetable family grouping for crop rotation is:
questions.explain: Tomatoes, peppers, and eggplant are Solanaceae and often share pests/diseases.

questions.q: Why are onions and garlic often planted early in cool seasons?
choices: They require tropical heat to form bulbs
They tolerate cool weather and can establish before heat
questions.explain: Alliums tolerate cooler conditions and benefit from early establishment.

questions.q: Which statement about compost and fertilizer is most accurate?
choices: Compost improves soil properties; fertilizer supplies concentrated nutrients
Compost is only sand and silt
questions.explain: Compost primarily improves soil condition; fertilizer is mainly nutrient supply.

questions.q: Why is “site selection” so critical for plant success?
choices: It matches species needs (light, moisture, wind, soil) to conditions
questions.explain: Right plant/right place reduces stress and improves long-term performance.

questions.q: A practical sign a shrub is too shaded is:
choices: Leggy growth with sparse foliage and reduced bloom
questions.explain: Low light often causes elongated, weak growth and fewer flowers.

questions.q: Why is it risky to prune spring-flowering shrubs (like lilac) in late winter?
choices: You may remove flower buds formed the previous season
questions.explain: Many spring bloomers set buds on last year’s growth; late-winter pruning removes those buds.

questions.q: Why do some gardeners prefer drip irrigation for disease-prone crops like tomatoes?
choices: It keeps foliage drier than overhead watering
questions.explain: Keeping foliage drier reduces foliar disease pressure compared with frequent overhead watering.

questions.q: Which is the best description of “allelopathy” in horticulture?
choices: A plant releasing chemicals that affect growth of other plants
questions.explain: Allelopathy refers to chemical interactions that can suppress or alter neighboring plant growth.
